articles.headline: Iran Exonerates Six Who Killed in Islam’s Name
articles.snippet: Members of a prestigious state militia killed five people they considered “morally corrupt.”
articles.abstract: Members of a prestigious state militia killed five people they considered “morally corrupt.”
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN, April 18 — The Iranian Supreme Court has overturned the murder convictions of six members of a prestigious state militia who killed five people they considered “morally corrupt.”

articles.headline: Software by Microsoft Is Nearly Free for the Needy
articles.snippet: Microsoft plans to offer a stripped-down version of Windows, Office and other software for $3 to people in developing nations.
articles.abstract: Microsoft plans to offer a stripped-down version of Windows, Office and other software for $3 to people in developing nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an effort to expand its global reach in computing, Microsoft plans to offer a stripped-down version of Windows, Office and other software for $3 to people in developing nations.

articles.headline: Officials Knew Troubled State of Killer in ’05
articles.snippet: The Virginia Tech gunman’s behavior had resulted in an effort to have him committed to a mental institution.
articles.abstract: The Virginia Tech gunman’s behavior had resulted in an effort to have him committed to a mental institution.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 18 — Campus authorities were aware 17 months ago of the troubled mental state of the student who shot and killed 32 people at Virginia Tech on Monday, an imbalance graphically on display in vengeful videos and a manifesto he mailed to NBC News in the time between the two sets of shootings.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Marc Santora

articles.headline: A Music Player That Needs Seasoning
articles.snippet: The Sansa Connect offers access to two million songs through Yahoo. Yes, there’s a catch.
articles.abstract: The Sansa Connect offers access to two million songs through Yahoo. Yes, there’s a catch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the iPod became a culture-changing phenomenon, Apple’s rivals have been desperate to discover the recipe for an iPod beater.

articles.headline: Wave of Bombings Continues in Iraq
articles.snippet: A suicide bomber killed 10 people in a religiously mixed neighborhood today, the day after attacks killed 171.
articles.abstract: A suicide bomber killed 10 people in a religiously mixed neighborhood today, the day after attacks killed 171.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 19 — Bombs ravaged Baghdad in five horrific explosions aimed mainly at Shiite crowds on Wednesday, killing at least 171 people in the deadliest day in the capital since the American-led security plan for the city took effect two months ago.

articles.headline: Bereft of BlackBerrys, the Untethered Make Do
articles.snippet: The 10-hour BlackBerry blackout revealed just how dependent so many people are on their electronic lifelines.
articles.abstract: The 10-hour BlackBerry blackout revealed just how dependent so many people are on their electronic lifelines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Where were you when the BlackBerrys went out?

articles.headline: Wall Street Journal Names Its New Top Editor
articles.snippet: Marcus W. Brauchli will succeed Paul E. Steiger in one of the most powerful jobs in business journalism.
articles.abstract: Marcus W. Brauchli will succeed Paul E. Steiger in one of the most powerful jobs in business journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: The competition for the most powerful position in business journalism ended yesterday as Marcus W. Brauchli was named managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, succeeding Paul E. Steiger, who has held the top job in the newsroom since 1991.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Laws Limit Options When a Student Is Mentally Ill
articles.snippet: For the most part, universities cannot tell parents about their children’s problems without the student’s consent.
articles.abstract: For the most part, universities cannot tell parents about their children’s problems without the student’s consent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal privacy and antidiscrimination laws restrict how universities can deal with students who have mental health problems.

articles.headline: Eastern Europe Becomes a Center for Outsourcing
articles.snippet: A few urban areas of the former Communist bloc are transforming into outsourcing centers for corporations in the U.S. and Europe.
articles.abstract: A few urban areas of the former Communist bloc are transforming into outsourcing centers for corporations in the U.S. and Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — Fillip Pejfar works in a sparkling new office tower here on the western edge of the Czech capital, using high-resolution scanners to enter accounting material into the computing systems of Accenture, the global business consulting group.
